div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY-THREE HINDOOS.
MEMORANDUM BRIEF OF PETITIONERS. REPLY BRIEF.
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY AT LAW 430-431-432-433 PIONEER BUILDING PHONE MAIN 1278 SEATTLE, WASH.
MERCHANTS PRINTING CO., TIMES BLDG., SEATTLE
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION, MAY TERM, 1913.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY- THREE HINDOO ALIENS. : : : NO. 2532. BILL OF EXCEPTIONS.

BE IT REMEMBERED: That in the May term, 1913, came the seventy-three Hindoo aliens into the said court and im- pleaded the United States of America in a certain petition for writs of habeas corpus on the ground of the unlawful detention of the said aliens; a show cause order was issued out of the United States District Court and in due time the United States made a return from said order and petition for writs of habeas corpus, admitting and denying allegations in the petition, and the United States further tendered the record as taken before the Immigration Department; a hearing was had on the 18th day of August, 1913, and the same was continued until the 26th day of August, 1913, and the court took the matter under advisement; the court thereupon rendered a verbal opinion, after which a rehearing was asked for by the petitioners, and the matter came on for hearing on the petition of the aliens on the 16th day of September, 1913, after which, on September 27, 1913, the court signed and filed an order refusing to grant the writs and discharging the govern- ment on the show cause order, to all of which petitioners excepted as herein set forth:
The learned judge erred in refusing to grant the writs of habeas corpus and in refusing to release the aliens.
-II-
The learned judge erred in refusing to release the aliens on the hearing on the show cause order on the ground that the government's return was not sufficient.
-III-
The learned judge erred in refusing to release the aliens and failing to grant the writs prayed for on the rehearing.
-IV-
The learned judge erred in holding the decision of the Immigration Department final and in failing to examine the evidence.

The learned judge erred in refusing to find that the petitioners had been deprived of their constitutional rights under Articles V, VI, VIII, and XIV of the Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.
-VI-
The learned judge erred in not holding that the second examination at Seattle was improper.
-VII-
The learned judge erred in refusing to hold that the examination at Manila was sufficient.
-VIII-
The learned judge erred in refusing to find that the warrants of arrest were not faulty and contrary to law.
-IX-
The learned judge erred in refusing to find that the examination was not fair and impartial.
The learned judge erred in refusing to find that the Immigration Department violated the Act of February 20, 1907.
-XI-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that the Immigration officals transcended the bound of their authority.
-XII-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that the warrants were issued contrary to law, and the entire proceeding was in direct violation of the Act of February 20, 1907.
-XIII-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that the Immigration officals had abused their authority and discretion
-XIV-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that the second examination was improper, after a previous proper examination.
-XV-

The learned judge erred in failing to find that the aliens had never become public charges and had never entered the country unlawfully and were, therefore, not properly held under the Act of February 20, 1907.
-XVI-
The learned judge erred in refusing to find that there was no proper, material or substantial evidence showing the aliens to come within the confines of the Act of February 20, 1907.
-XVII-
The learned judge erred in refusing to find that the aliens had been properly examined and passed by an Immigration Board at Manila.
-XVIII-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that the petitioners had had no hearing on the ground of exclusion.
-XIX-
The learned judge erred in refusing to find that the aliens were not amenable to the law.
-XX-

The learned judge erred in failing to find that the positive proof furnished by the aliens as to their proper landing in Manila was sufficient to overcome any presumption as outlined in Rule 14 of the Immigration Act.
-XXI-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that Section 20 of the Immigration Act was mandatory.
-XXII-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that the Immigration authorities had not complied with Rule 22 of the Immigration Act.
-XXIII-
The learned judge erred in failing to find that Section 25 of the Immigration Act had no application to the cases of these aliens.
-XXIV-

And to each and every of the rulings of the court to which objection was made and exception was noted, as herein- before set forth, the petitioners now, within the time prescribed by law, present this bill of exceptions as to each and every of
the rulings on objections as aforesaid, move the court to sign the same, to have the same force and effect as if each and every of said exceptions had been separately signed and sealed, and thereupon the petitioners pray that this bill of exceptions may be signed and sealed and made a part of the record according to the form of the statute in such case made and provided, which is done accordingly this 8th day of October, 1913.
Jeremiah Neterer District Judge.
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY- THREE HINDOO ALIENS.
BILL OF EXCEPTIONS.
Received a copy of the within this 8th day of October, 1913 E B Brockway Asst Dist Atty
FILED IN THE U.S. DISTRICT COURT, Western Dist. of Washington NORTHERN DIVISION. OCT 23 1913. FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk, By Emy Deputy
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY AT LAW 430-431-432-433 PIONEER BUILDING PHONE MAIN 1278 SEATTLE, WASH. MERCHANTS PRINTING CO., TIMES BLDG., SEATTLE
